content.description: Some interesting, balancey moves get you up the slab on the right side of the arete.
content.location: The line of bolts up the right side of the arete. Right of King of Swing crack.

content.description:
Good moves on wide gear in a corner just left of the sandy start to Freeblast.  Traverse up and left to a corner, utilizing both the corner and horizontals for holds and gear.  Top out on a slopey, leaf-covered shallow gulley.

Not a stellar line by any stretch of the imagination, as it is short, and is dirty from lack of traffic.  However, it can be a good place for new leaders to practice.  The gear is solid and plentiful, and is a welcome moderate gear line in a sea of harder sport and trad lines.
content.protection: Everything from 5 to .75.  Bring long cord or get creative with your rope to extend an anchor over the lip of the route, as the only trees worth anchoring to are at least 15 feet from the edge.
content.location: A short walk upstream from Sandstonia and the classic Decameron.  If you get to the finger crack King of Swing, you have gone too far.

content.description: This route angles up and right past a few bolts and some thin, technical pocket pulling until eventually finishing around the arete on the last bolts of Solitude Standing.
content.location: Starts on a crack/flake feature about 10' right of King of Swing.

content.description: Beautiful splitter crack with an extremely fun start. Finger and hand jam up to the bolts from there.
content.protection: Stoppers and cams up to BD #2
content.location: Hike down the Kingfish trail and turn right. It will be the obvious splitter shortly after turning off the descent trail.

content.description:
Start right of the big oak (the one with the hole on the side facing the wall). Climb the crack and top out.

You can set this up for TR if you place a redirect at the tree just above the crack (which you might have slung before topping out) and walking on the outer edge to the rap station where you can then set your own anchor and beaners to TR off of.

The anchor with the tree just above the crack becomes the climber side and the anchor on the rap tree becomes the belay side.
content.protection:
Route eats hand size gear and smaller.

Rap station to right at larger tree.
content.location: Follow power lines to sign for kingfish wall, follow then hug right wall past very large (80'?) broken roof to large oak tree in corner with hole on rock side of the tree.

content.description: Scramble up to the flake. Layback up the thin flake to the roof, then pump through some steep moves on good holds to the anchors.
content.protection: 4 bolts.  Bring a green BD camalot to protect between the 2nd and 3rd bolts and it makes it a lot safer. 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Left of King of Swing. The line of bolts up the right facing flake below the roof.

content.description:
Layback up the nice flake to to a perch left of the large chimney. Pull the roof around the left side and rappel from the pine on the ledge.

Bring your big gear for the flake.
content.protection:
The first piece of directional gear is a BD #3, you need a #6 to get protection 15' up, after this your best bet is to sling the top of the flake before pulling the ledge.

After the ledge you have flakes to the right and a roof crack above you, choose wisely.

No anchor, rap at tree.
content.location: Take trail from power lines to the Kingfish wall and follow right, past the large 80' broken roof, round the corner to a chimney. There is a large flake on the ground which marks the start.
